text.body:
The main eCommerce website for Tommy Bahama was being moved to a new platform and at the same time, it was getting a aesthetic refresh.

I was tasked at picking up this project that had been partially completed. While the previous owner of the project had done quite a bit of work, I had the disadvantage of not having a lot of background before being thrown into this project. A lot of the styling was inconsistent and I had to go through and make sure that consistency was put in place, so that future revisions could be made easier. I was responsible for final styling decisions and working with the developers to get changes done in a very short period of time.

An added obstacle in the site revision, was that, there were few layout changes that could be made in the amount of time allotted. Aesthetic changes needed to be carefully considered, while maintaining business needs. The ask was for the site to have a lighter, more modern aesthetic, while allowing the product to shine. Simplicity was the approach that I took, in order to let the product speak for itself. Some minor navigation changes helped declutter the home page, while button colors were consolidated to reflect a more cohesive and consistent visual language.

After the main site revision, the business team felt that it would be in the best interest of the company to get all of the eCommerce sites to look as cohesive as possible. I was tasked with restyling the entire outlet site, while maintaining the integrity of the content layout.

After having gone through the initial struggle of figuring out all the components for the main site, I was able to streamline the redlining process, as well as produce a more comprehensive style guide for development.

The end result was a much cleaner and integrated look and feel than the previous version of the outlet site.

FPO COPY Tommy Bahama sends out over 400 emails a year, and that isn’t including the geo-targeted ones. I have done my fair share of them.

They range from simple templated emails to quick-turn custom messaging that was “due yesterday”, even though you received the brief an hour ago.

The fun and quirky neighborhood of Fremont in Seattle was in need of a digital portal where the art director and artists could connect for the monthly artwalk. It also needed to be a place where attendees could find information quickly.

I used illustrations of the neighborhood icons and bright colors to capture the eccentricity of the neighborhood, while utilizing a straightforward and easy to navigate layout to make it easy for both participants and attendees to get the information they needed.

FPO COPY During my last year or so at Zumiez, the private label team was asked to design and produce price-point conscience private label longboard line.

I worked with buying team to come up with the the board shapes and construction. Once we finalized the technical aspects with the manufacturer, we customized wheels and trucks as well as worked on creating various designs to go on the bottom sides of the boards.

While working in house for the Zumiez private label team, I got the opportunity to work on a number of different apparel brands. Each brand targeted a different segment of a similar demographic. The brands, which catered to 13-25 year old skateboarders and snowboarders, ran from technical to trendy, with a little bit of everything in between.

The samples seen here are just a few examples of apparel packaging that I designed while I was there. Most packaging groups usually contained well over 50+ items per group, with 3-4 packaging groups being developed at one time. I concepted, designed, created production files, tracked, worked with domestic and overseas vendors, to produce samples and made all final approvals that came through.

FPO COPY In my free time, I freelance and volunteer with a number of promoters and organizations to create event promotions. These are a number of posters that I created for a few groups. Most of the posters usually had an accompanying flyer. Sometimes I would be asked to create additional collateral including lapel pins, merch and social media assets.

FPO COPY T-shirts were a staple business at Zumiez when I was working there. 5-10 tees would be designed on a monthly basis, all of which had to be on trend, timely, and desirable.

On top of designing, I also created all of the technical packages that accompanies most apparel design, which includes all the measurements and details the end product should have.

I worked directly with domestic and overseas vendors to get the artwork I designed, produced.

There were also times when I was asked to art direct third party vendors, whom I would provide trend analysis,

Working on the private label team at Zumiez allowed me to develop a lot of new skills. One of those skills was textile printing. My patterns adorned everything from apparel to backpacks, wallets, belts, the list goes on. I was able to utilize various types of techniques including sublimation, discharge printing, silk-screen, as well as large scale engineered prints.

Shameless productions decided that they wanted to move beyond club nights and asked me to help design their first album cover and all the collateral that came along with that. On top of the album artwork, I also did all social and online advertising assets, posters, flyers and merchandise design.
This annual picnic needed a simple RSVP card for guests to send back with important information for the host. It was inspired by vintage firework packaging.
